awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Stimulation on Demand: Responsive Deep Brain Stimulation for the Treatment of Tourette Syndrome
awd_abstract_narration:
The human brain consists of numerous networks distributed over space and connected over time to orchestrate meaningful interaction with the external world. Neurological disorders disrupt this interaction, as well as our control over our bodies. Deep brain stimulation (DBS) has emerged in the nineties as a neurosurgical intervention for the treatment of movement disorders. The principle behind DBS is to implant electrodes into deep brain structures and to inject electrical pulses to suppress pathological brain activity. The clinical personnel that perform programming of stimulation settings however, base their decisions on the observable patient responses rather than a scientific understanding of the underlying pathology, or the physiological response to stimulation. The PI's proposed effort includes studying the neural signatures of movement disorders, and the aftereffects of stimulation to provide insight into treatment options that can be tailored to the current clinical condition of the patient. Responsive DBS is expected to provide improved symptom suppression, reduce adverse effects of continuous stimulation, and prolong battery life of DBS implants. This project will also provide students in the PI's lab with an environment that promotes learning in the design of neural engineering systems, data collection in clinical settings, and analysis of large-scale datasets. All of these skills are prolific to the development of translational medicine applications for those suffering from disabilities, and to the education of the next generation of biomedical engineers.

The overall research goal of this project is to study the electrophysiological underpinnings of neurological disorders using next generation DBS devices capable of recording brain signals in humans, in order to responsively deliver stimulation to the current pathological state of the brain. To this end, the PI is investigating the neurophysiology of Tourette syndrome, which affects an estimated 3 to 9 school-age children in 1000, and to develop responsive DBS systems for its improved and targeted treatment in humans. Online classifieres will be built to detect involuntary tics that characterize Tourette syndrome from neural activity in the centromedian nucleus of the thalamus and the motor cortex. The input-output relationship between DBS parameters and neural activity will be studied to build inverse adaptive controllers that will yield optimal stimulation parameters. The knowledge gained from this project and the established platform can be extended to other movement disorders. The overall objective of the educational plan is to increase interest and engagement in STEM fields and to proliferate the study of engineering through a series of focused educational activities at the K-12, undergraduate, and graduate education levels.

The project will be co-funded by the Activation and Modulation Programs in the Neural Systems cluster of MCB and, therefore, is eligible for BioMaps co-funding.

por.por_cntn:
Deep brain stimulation (DBS) has emerged in the nineties as a neurosurgical intervention for the treatment of movement disorders. The principle behind DBS is to implant electrodes into deep brain structures to modulate the pathological activity causing disabling symptoms by injecting electrical pulses. The clinical personnel that perform programming of stimulation settings (amplitude, frequency, and pulse width of the electrical current) however, they do not necessarily have a scientific understanding of the underlying pathology, or the physiological response to the adjustments to various stimulation parameters. Instead, they base their decisions on the observable behavioral responses and verbal response of patients. Studying the neurophysiological signatures of neurological disorders, and the aftereffects of brain stimulation would enable direct interpretation of the disorder and provide insight into treatment options that can be tailored to the current clinical condition of the patient. The overall research goal of this project was to study the electrophysiological underpinnings of movement disorders using next generation DBS devices capable of recording brain signals in humans, to responsively deliver stimulation to the current pathological state of the brain. 

For this project, we studied the neurophysiology of Tourette Syndrome (TS), which affects an estimated 3 to 9 school-age children in 1000 and developed a responsive DBS system for the improved and targeted treatment of TS in humans. TS is a complex neuropsychiatric disorder characterized by involuntary and urge–driven motor and vocal tics. It is associated with significant morbidity, social embarrassment, functional impairment, and in severe cases self-injurious behavior. The exact causes of TS remain unknown. 

Our first research objective was to characterize and detect pathological brain states in TS from multisite chronic recording in a first-in-human system. We were able to accurately detect involuntary tics from deep brain regions as they manifested, while distinguishing them from voluntary movements. In contrast, the motor cortex, the area of our brain that execute movements, could not distinguish incoming signals associated with involuntary tics from voluntary movement commands. This understanding of tic genesis will advance TS therapies even beyond DBS therapy. For instance, we have developed a brain signal based method for neurosurgeons to place the electrodes during implantation surgery for maximum symptom relief, which was beyond the goals of this project. 

The second objective of this research project was to develop a DBS system that can initiate stimulation to the input received from the brain signals. This is called a closed-loop DBS system. We showed that a DBS system capable of detecting the pathological activity, and providing stimulation in a responsive manner, improved symptom suppression and prolong battery life of the implant. Furthermore, we showed the developed system was safe and did not cause any side effects that are observed with continuous stimulation. This in turn significantly improves the lives of those suffering from movement disorders. 

 

This funding supported research training opportunities for two graduate students, four undergraduate students, and five high school students. This funding also supported development of training modules to expose high school students to engineering design for translational medicine applications. These modules were presented through collaboration with the UF Center for Precollegiate Education and Training at the Summer Science Training Program to dozens of Florida students. 

 

For this project, the principal investigator has been awarded the Presidential Early Career Award for Scientists and Engineers (PECASE) based on the NSF’s recommendation. PECASE the highest honor bestowed by the U.S. government on outstanding scientists and engineers beginning their independent careers. The knowledge gained from this project and the established platform have now been extended to other movement disorders at the University of Florida as part of the principal investigator’s long-term career plan.
